Broke four-minute mile in 1954: stored carbohydrates. Body runs low around 90 minutes of running.
seasonal approach to running w/ distinct phases; e.g., base training, strength-building, competition, recovery. works well for elite runners.
intensity level at which anaerobic energy production begins to negatively impact performance
energy created within cells without oxygen, created when body needs energy faster than body can produce with oxygen
maximum amount of oxygen your body can consume within a minute
how efficiently you use oxygen at give pace
byproduct of anaerobic energy production
how much blood your heart can pump with each beat
maintaining same pace for each running split
picking up pace during later splits in run
sustained run (10-40 min+) at 'comfortably hard' pace you could maintain at least an hour
Swedish for 'speed play'. unstructured blend of different paces aimed at challenging both aerobic and anaerobic fitness.
in race, each runner's finish time is scored as a percentage of maximum performance expected based on runner's age
cellular structures responsible for producing all aerobic energy
aka, muscle cell
bundles of muscle fibers. many of these are bundled together to form skeletal muscles.
muscle fibers that contract more slowly, and have higher aerobic endurance potential
large muscle fibers that contract forcefully & quickly, but with limited aerobic potential
use either just slow-twitch (low intensity), combo of slow & intermediate twitch, or slow/intermediate/fast twitch (high intensity) fibers
body-weight exercises focused on exercising large muscle groups
5-20s of 'fast' running, mimicking race paces (not sprints)
amount of blood heart can pump in a minute
aka, capillary growth
when you engage additional muscles (abs, internal intercostals) to help exhale faster during intense exercise
one of muscles used for breathing; contract to inhale, relax to exhale
extraction of oxygen from capilaries, bringing them into muscle fibers, and using them to make aerobic energy
subcellular structure that performs a specialized task
